column4: That's a difficult question since there are a lot of different ways to do a "fresh install"
Your "fresh install" may include apps that others don't choose to install.
include what apps? from what I've seen from oneiric, the only option you have is a check for some proprietary MP3 package
So when you installed you just did a default install?  You didn't manually choose applications to install?
does Oneiric allow you to pikc up random apps to install? I didn't see that option
The standard installer doesn't.  I just installs a predefined group of applications.
I didn't know there were other official installers, I couldn't notice them on the download page. Where are them and what are their purpose?
For advanced users or for those that was a server rather than a desktop.
ok, it's not hard even in that case
it's just about knowing which non-default stuff was installed even if during system install
You may be able to look at the list of apps installed by default and compare to what you have installed.
Pretty sure the apps installed by default are available in the read me or in the documentation somewhere.

I could play with apt history but it's boring... I could keep myself some history, I could  add some function like install { sudo apt-get install "$@" && add-to-install-history }... but I wanted a ready-to-use solution
I don't know of anything like that.  Someone else may though.

as for standard apps listed somewhere I'm not so sure, it would rather be a deb package list and comparing it to current installed packages would not give the apps since they may consist on several dependencies
thanks anyway Jet
if I had time I'd just write some gui for that function or maybe patching software center or synaptic, it would be really nice to have something similar to the add/remove panel from windows
Well Ubuntu doesn't "officially" use DEB anymore I think.  It CAN use them but It officially uses the Software Center now.
what do you exactly mean with 'DEB'?
Well, I know there is some kind of difference between the package managers for Ubuntu and Debian.
what package managers? apt? aptitude? synaptic? software center?
what just happened is that they just wrote software center as alternative to synaptic and removed this one from oneiric as installed by default
I've seen the (btw buggy) filter dialog of synaptic, never seen a way to create such a filter though
Just a suggestion.
ok, but from what I've seen it's not possible :(
Well, looks like you may just have to roll your own then.  :|
yeah :( thanks anyway
Drive space is so cheep now that I don't think many folks care what's on their system.
it's not a matter of disk usage
it's a matter of knowing what custom applications you've installed, just like in add/remove dialog in windows
I know what you mean.  Just not many folks out there use an application to track their apps I guess.
